title: I live in California and owe Washington State Unemployment for Overpayment. Can this debt be declared in bankruptcy?
question: I am underwater and will likely have to file for bankruptcy. I owe about $30K to WA state for overpayment of unemployment benefits. Since this amount is the bulk of the debt if I can't discharge the Unemployment debt it doesn't make sense to declare bankruptcy. I'm divorced and employed. I live in a 5th wheel which I now own outright and have. 2012 car that is also unencumbered.
question_tags: Child support,Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Debt relief,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Fraud,Child support and unemployment,Unemployment compensation
answers:
The short answer is yes. To deny discharge they would have to file a Complaint to determine that the debt was caused by intentional fraud. I have been doing this for over 40 years and so far I have never seen California file such an action. I doubt Washington would bother either.

What I would be concerned about is:
1) Whether you have been in California long enough to qualify to use the California exemption system. It is better than the Washington exemptions. We would need to determine whether you can protect your 5th wheel or your vehicle. You may not want to file bankruptcy right now. It is impossible to tell until the attorney can go over where you were living over the last 2 1/2 years.
2) What debts you were ordered or agreed to pay under a marital settlement agreement? You may find that you can get rid of the debt to the creditor but, if you were ordered to pay the debt rather than your exspouse, you could be liable to your exspouse if they have to pay the creditor. They can go into the family law court and have you ordered to "indemnify" or pay them back what they had to pay.

That is just a couple of issues that need to be looked at before you file a bankruptcy.

Your case will be handled in the Sacramento Bankruptcy Court. I would recommend you find a quality bankruptcy attorney by looking at Avvo's own ratings of attorneys in the Sacramento region. There are several that have 10.0 Avvo ratings.

You could also look at the CA State bar website for a Certified Bankruptcy Law Specialist in or around the Sacramento region. Most attorneys will give you are free initial consultation. I have provided a link to the state bar below.

California State Bar Certified Specialist Search
http://members.calbar.ca.gov/search/ls_search.aspx

Another potential source for finding a good attorney would be through a search of the National Association of Consumer Bankruptcy Attorneys (NACBA.org) to find a good local attorney. Again, I have provided a link below.

National Association of Consumer Bankruptcy Attorneys
http://www.nacba.org/find-an-attorney

Hope this helps.

So long as there is no fraud involved, the over payment should be listed as an outstanding debt and discharged. More information is needed and you should immediately consult with an experienced Debt Relief or Bankruptcy attorney in your area. There is no substitute for an in person consultation with an experienced attorney in your area. They will know the lay of the land in your area.

If possible you should consult in person with a qualified Debt Relief or Bankruptcy Attorney, or your local Legal Aid Office. This is not legal advice. You need to speak to an attorney who is licensed in your state for legal advice. This is merely suggestions for you to think about in discussing your situation with the local attorney.

The overpayment can be discharged provided there was no fraud on your part resulting in the overpayment. For example: You continued to accept unemployment money when you were working and knew you were not entitled to it.

Your first mistake is not finding and discussing in person with an experienced bankruptcy attorney as this is just a general forum. The answer is as follows : Yes..Yes as can this "be declared". Why? Because you should already know ALL debts must be declared and listed in ANY bankruptcy.

Your next issue is it discharged? No attorney can advise you of that in fact! Why? Because Wa State would have to be listed as creditor to receive notice. Then WA must decide whether in fact they should object to your discharge based on an exception to the bankruptcy code including fraud. Many persons may file untrue requests for unemployment, but the WA ST does NOT file adversary cases in all of those! Thus, if not filed, then it will in fact be discharged..something you wont know until the deadline is reached.

Then even if sued, the issue is did you or them make a mistake or did you perform an act which constitutes an exception to discharge.

Finally, even if in fact discharged, if later you try and apply for unemployment benefits from WA ST, they may offset that amount you discharged from your first payments too.

In short, you always need an attorney as other facts and issues can also affect your case so I will point those out for you also!
You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!

Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof!

Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.

But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.

Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.

You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.
